ES‐1 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E) is committed to become the safest, most reliable natural gas

system in the nation. This vision will be achieved through the Gas Safety Excellence framework. The

strategy is to deliver Gas Safety Excellence by putting safety and people at the heart of everything;

investing in the reliability and integrity of our gas system; and by continuously improving the

effectiveness and affordability of our processes. Strategic actions developed under this strategy are

aligned under three elements of a safety management system that: (1) develop an asset management

strategy to appropriately invest in the integrity and reliability of the gas system; (2) nurture a safety‐first

culture that places safety at the heart of everything it does; and (3) focus on process safety in all

activities to minimize the possibility of high consequence events. PG&E has prepared an emergency

response plan as an element of its Hazardous Materials Business Plan to handle potential accidental

releases of compressed natural gas.



ES‐2 CNG Fueling Facility Description

The Manteca Compressed Natural Gas (CNG) Fueling Facility is located on the south side of W. Yosemite

Avenue, one mile west of the City of Manteca in San Joaquin, California. The City of Manteca

Wastewater Treatment Plant is located south and west of the facility. A residential area is situated east

and north of the facility. A light industrial development is located to the northwest.

The CNG Fueling Facility consists of the following: utility meter set; gas dryer; fixed and portable

compressors to boost utility pipeline pressure of 30 pounds per square inch gauge (psig) to 2,400 to

4,100 psig; three CNG storage vessels; fast‐fill CNG dispenser; PLC based gas flow control equipment;

eight fill posts for filling portable CNG trailers; space for fueling of 17 portable CNG equipment trailers;

m

onitoring, controls, and safety systems.



ES‐3 Accidental Release Prevention Program Summary

The Manteca CNG Fueling Facility can potentially contain up to 63,000 pounds of compressed natural

gas, of which up to 1,730 pounds are in fixed storage vessels, equipment, and piping with the remainder

in portable CNG trailers that may be filled and stored at the facility. Since the quantity of CNG onsite

exceeds both the CalARP regulation applicability threshold as well as the Process Safety Management

(PSM) standard (8 CCR 5189) applicability threshold, the CNG Fueling Facility is subject to CalARP

requirements as well as the PSM requirements.

The Manteca CNG Fueling Facility Accidental Release Prevention Program includes the following

10 elements:

1. Management System

2. Process Safety Information

3. Process Hazard Analysis

4. Operating Procedures

5. Training

6. Mechanical Integrity

7. Management of Change

8. Pre‐startup Safety Review

9. Compliance Audits

10. Incident Investigation



Management System

PG&E has developed a management system to oversee implementation of the Accidental Release

Prevention Program. The Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG)/Compressed Natural Gas (CNG) Engineering

Manager has been assigned as the qualified person with overall responsibility for the development,

implementation, and integration of the risk management program elements. The management system

describes assignments of positions responsible for implementing individual RMP elements.



Process Safety Information

Complete and up‐to‐date safety information is required to successfully implement most RMP elements

including process hazard analyses, training, emergency planning and response, management of change,

incident investigation, and compliance audits. Process safety information includes safety information

associated with compressed natural gas as described in the safety data sheet and safety information

associated with the process technol

ogy and equipment. PG&E has verified that the system is designed

with recognized and generally accepted good engineering processes by specifying current codes and

standards to be used for facility construction.



Process Hazard Analysis

A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) is a systematic evaluation of the potential causes and consequences of

accidental releases with the objective of eliminating conditions that contribute to a high risk of release

of CNG. The PHA addresses the following:

 Hazards of the CNG fueling process

 Previous incidents which had likely potential for catastrophic consequences

 Engineering and administrative controls

 Consequences of failure of engineering and administrative controls

 Facility siting

 Human factors

 Qualitative evaluation of health and safety effects of failure of controls

 External events including seismic events

An initial PHA was performed on March 25 and 26, 2015 based on the 60 percent design package, and

was updated on March 30 and 31, 2016 based on Issued‐for‐Permit design package using a combination

of the HAZOP and What‐if/Checklist methods. The PHA was facilitated and recorded by PG&E staff with

experience in the PHA methods used. The PHA team included staff with expertise in engineering and

process operations associated with CNG fueling facilities.

PG&E established a system to address the PHA findings and recommendations, consisting of a written

summary table with an implementation schedule and assignment of responsibilities. The LNG/CNG

Engineering Manager is assigned overall responsibility for tracking PHA findings and recommendations.

Findings and recommendations will be addressed by September 30, 2018 according to a schedule

agreed to with the San Joaquin County Environmental Health Department.

In addition to addressing PHA findings and prior to commissioning the CNG facility, a design review was

conducted to id

entify all changes implemented since the original PHA was conducted. The design

changes were itemized, reviewed and approved by the design team on April 27, 2017.



Operating Procedures

PG&E maintains up‐to‐date operating procedures for the CNG Fueling Process. The operating

procedures address startup, normal operations, emergency shutdowns, emergency operations, normal

shutdowns, and startup following a turnaround or emergency shutdown. Operating procedures contain

information on operating limits, consequences of deviation from operating limits, and steps to correct or

avoid deviations. Operating procedures also contain safety and health considerations including the

following:

 CNG properties and hazards

 Release and exposure prevention precautions such as engineering controls, administrative controls,and personal protective equipment

 Control measures if a release/exposure occurs

 Quality control for materials and inventory

 Special hazards

Finally, operating procedures also contain information on safety systems and their functions.

PG&E also has developed and implemented safe work practices to control potential hazards including

lockout/tagout, confined space entry, opening process equipment or piping, and controlling

entrance/access to the CNG Fueling Facility.

Operating procedures are maintained in the paper and electronic files at the facility. Staff is trained

regarding how to readily access operating procedures. The LNG/CNG South Maintenance and

Operations (M&O) Supervisor is responsible for reviewing the operating procedures as often as is

required and at least annually. The LNG/CNG South M&O Supervisor or the LNG/CNG Engineering

Manager certifies annually that the operating procedures are current and accurate.



Training

PG&E employees are trained in an overview of the process as well as in the written operating

procedures before they may operate the CNG Fueling Facility and are p

rovided with refresher training at

least every 3 years on frequency established by the LNG/CNG South M&O Supervisor in consultation

with affected employees. Training records are maintained at the facility.



Mechanical Integrity

PG&E uses Computerized Maintenance Management Software to schedule maintenance inspections,

testing, preventive maintenance, and corrective actions for the CNG Fueling Facility based on

manufacturer's equipment manuals and other written procedures. The LNG/CNG South M&O Supervisor

is responsible to assure that maintenance materials, spare parts, and equipment are suitable for the

process and represent "replacement‐in‐kind" unless such materials, spare parts, and equipment have

been evaluated and approved through the Management of Change process. The LNG/CNG South M&O

Supervisor is also responsible for training staff involved in maintaining the system. Training records are

maintained at the facility.



Management of Change

PG&E has implemented written Management of Change (MOC) procedures to manage changes to

process technology, equipment, documentation and procedures and to the physical facility

infrastructure that might affect the CNG Fueling Facility. In the event that there is a change to the CNG

Fueling Facility other than "replacement‐in‐kind", PG&E will evaluate the change, including the technical

basis, impact on safety and health, need for new/modified operating procedures, implementation

schedule, and authorization requirements at which point a decision will be made on how to proceed.

Facility staff with responsibilities affected by the change is informed of, and trained on, the change prior

to startup and affected process safety information, operating procedures, and mechanical integrity

procedures are updated.



Pre‐Startup Safety Review

PG&E performed a pre‐startup safety review (PSSR), using a PSSR checklist, when the CNG Fueling

Facility was initially commissioned. Upo

n any modification significant enough to require a change in

process safety information, a PSSR will again be utilized for commissioning the modified system. The

PSSR verifies that the facility and equipment are in accordance with design specifications; safety,

operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and adequate, a PHA has been

performed if needed, and recommendations, if any, have been addressed before startup, and

employees have been trained.



Compliance Audits

PG&E staff, including at least one person knowledgeable of the CNG Fueling Process, perform

compliance audits at least every 3 years to verify that the prevention program procedures and practices

are being followed. PG&E will prepare a written audit report for the compliance audit. PG&E will

coordinate with the San Joaquin County Environmental Health Department on a schedule for resolution

of findings with a maximum completion date of 1.5 years after the date of the compliance audit.



Incident Investigation

PG&E has designed and constructed the CNG Fueling Facility and intends to maintain and operated it in

such a way to prevent CNG releases. However, in the event an incident occurs that results in or could

reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release of CNG, PG&E will investigate the incident as

promptly as possible, and no later than 48 hours after, the incident. The LNG/CNG Engineering Manager

will assign an incident investigation team including at least one person knowledgeable in the process

and will establish a system to address, resolve, and document findings and recommendations of the

written incident investigation report on a schedule established in consultation with the San Joaquin

County Environmental Health Department with a maximum completion date of 1.5 years after the

completion of the incident investigation or 2 years after the date of the incident. PG&E will review the

incident investigation report with affected personnel.



Employee Par

ticipation

PG&E has implemented a written plan of action for employee participation to include consulting with

employees on PHAs and other prevention program elements and providing employees with access to

PHAs and other prevention program documentation.



ES‐4 5‐Year Accident History

The CNG Fueling Facility is scheduled to start operations in mid‐2017. There have been no accidental

releases from the CNG Fueling Facility that have resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property

damage on site, or offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or

environmental damage.



ES‐5 Emergency Response Program

PG&E has prepared an emergency response plan for the CNG Fueling Facility as an element of its

Hazardous Materials Business Plan. PG&E has coordinated response actions with the City of Manteca

Fire Department.



ES‐6 Planned Changes to Improve Process Safety

Based on the PHA performed for the CNG Fueling Facility, PG&E identified 26 recommendations to

improve process safety of which 2 remain open as of June 1, 2017 with plans in place to have the

remaining 2 items resolved or addressed no later than September 30, 2018.
